moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 Bc5: The gambit is refused this time.
moves.3. Nf3 d6 4. b4: An uncharacteristic mistake by the pro.  This badly weakens White's Q-side.
moves.4... Bxb4 5. c3 Bc5: White continues to waste time with his Pawns, chasing after Black's Bishop.
moves.6. d4 exd4 7. cxd4: White is still down a Pawn and Black now has a huge endgame advantage with his powerful Q-side majority.
moves.7... Bb6 8. Bc4 Nf6: Black can answer 9 P-K5 with 9... P-Q4!
moves.9. Qd3 O-O 10. O-O Re8: Both players have developed their King-side but not the Q-side.
moves.11. Nbd2 g6 12. f5: The grandmaster tries to force an attack through. But with his Q-side undeveloped, the attack will lack sting.
moves.13. exd5 Bxf5 14. Qb3 Ng4: Now the attack passes to Black.
moves.16... Kg7 17. Qc4 Bd3: White resigns, as his KR will fall. A brilliant display of chess from the child.
